Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Advancing Women in Political Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Women comprise an unusually small percentage of tenured faculty in political science programs -- especially programs at research intensive institutions -- relative to the number of women who received PhDs in political science and who serve as assistant professors. This underrepresentation carries over into important aspects of their professional careers. For example, women authors tend to publish less frequently in top field journals, find their work cited less frequently, and are often evaluated differently than men across a range of indicators. This project seeks to identify the set of factors that help to explain why women are underrepresented in political science and to devise a mentoring program to assist women early in their careers. To do so, they propose to conduct a cohort study of individuals who attended graduate school in the 1990s. Next, they will administer a survey to learn more about perceptions of scholarly journals and publication success. Finally, they propose an experimental mentoring program to identify the most effective strategies for promoting success for female scholars in political science. The research team is comprised of a number of successful scholars, most of whom are women, and will have the support of the American Political Science Association in helping to administer the studies and implement the mentoring program.


This project examines the factors that lead to the significant underrepresentation of tenured women in political science. The percentage of women with tenure is lower than one would expect given the number of female PhDs and assistant professors. The proposal sets out to accomplish two things: evaluate factors that hinder the advancement of women in political science and generate evidence-based strategies to develop successful mentoring programs. A diverse team of accomplished scholars has been assembled to conduct this research. The project consists of three components. First, a team will conduct a survey to evaluate respondents' attitudes toward journals and perceptions of success with a particular focus on notable differences across an array of respondent characteristics. Second, they will conduct a cohort study comprised of individuals who entered graduate school in the 1990s and are currently mid-career scholars. Third, they will implement a randomized experimental mentoring program to assess the relative success of competing interventions. The project will work in conjunction with the American Political Science Association, thereby increasing its reach and enhancing the likelihood of increasing the number of tenured female scholars in political science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Task Force undertook to understand obstacles and identify strategies for women to advance and succeed in the profession of Political Science. We undertook studies to better understand the relationship between institutional and social contexts and individual choices, as well as potential obstacles that women face in the profession. Finally, we engaged in efforts to identify best practices to promote inclusion and equity for adoption by APSA, political science departments, and universities. The Task Force’s work focused on two broad categories— Data Collection and Studies; and Interventions and Outreach.

 

I. Data Collection and Studies

 1.       Longitudinal Data Project

The Task Force institutionalized a long-term data collection effort that tracks the career paths of women and underrepresented minorities through the career pipeline—the Project on Women and Minorities (P-WAM). We developed a new Qualtrics instrument that is now used to gather information annually from the largest Ph.D. and MA programs in political science across the country. Aggregate and (where possible) department level trends can be accessed on the APSA P-WAM website.

 2.       Cohort Study

 This group designed and completed a study of three program cohorts that entered graduate school in the early 1990s and are currently mid-career. This study presents original data based on online and in-person surveys, which provides rich qualitative evidence about how individuals make career decisions, how climate and experiences within departments and in the profession shape career trajectories, and how and why individuals choose to leave the profession. Their study was published and is publicly available for reading or for download here.

 3. Publications Studies

In one study, Brown and Samuels worked with the editors of five major journals to conduct internal audits to explore whether editorial and reviewer biases help to explain the gender publication gap identified by Teele and Thelen (“Gender in the Journals,” PS April 2017). They found little evidence of bias. The editors participated in a roundtable on gender in editorial processes at the San Francisco APSA meetings in 2017. The results were presented at the 2018 APSA meetings and were published in a symposium in PS.

In a second study, Samuels and Teele gathered data on gender balance in book publishing in political science between 2004 and 2015, to conduct analysis building on "Gender in the Journals.” A paper based on the results is publicly available here.

In a third study, Brown, Horiuchi, Htun, and Samuels administered a “supply-side” survey that asked respondents about their perceptions of 13 journals in political science and found gender perception gaps at some, but not all, leading journals. Results were presented at APSA and other meetings. An article based on the results is publicly accessible on SSRN.

 

II. Interventions and Outreach

 1. Mentoring Intervention

Based on extensive research about successful strategies used in other disciplines, this working group designed and began executing a mentoring plan administered as a randomized, controlled trial. All untenured women in the profession were invited to apply to the program, out of which some were randomly selected for a year of periodic mentoring by senior members of the profession. Several of the members of the Taskforce participated as mentors, first at a workshop at APSA’s headquarters in Washington D.C. in the fall of 2018, and in subsequent meetings with the junior faculty in the program. Mendelberg and Argyle studied the effects of different kinds of mentoring (career versus substantive feedback and in combination, for example). We expect this study will produce measurable and scalable results that could transform the way departments undertake mentoring of graduate students and untenured faculty.

2. Diversity and Inclusion Hackathon

The Task Force organized a Diversity and Inclusion Hackathon at the 2018 American Political Science Association Annual Meeting in Boston. This high-energy event brought together 11 teams of colleagues and approximately 300 participants who spent the day working collaboratively to address a wide range of issues relating to inclusion and diversity in the profession. Teams focused on how men can promote gender equality, minimum standards for employing contingent faculty, improving the climate for graduate students, designing institutions to encourage reporting of sexual assault and harassment, recruiting and retaining a diverse faculty, teaching intersectionality in political science, data visualization, and more. Mala Htun explained the philosophy and the impact of the hackathon in an article published in PS, available here.

 3.       Community building and networks

Based on the idea that social support networks help promote women’s retention in the profession, Sara Parker launched a column, “On My Own Terms,” on the website of the Committee on the Status of Women in the Profession (CSWP). The column is designed to offer insights and serve as a discussion forum for scholars who have chosen careers in community college or other non-research university settings.
